Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Automotive Tire Force and Moment Sensors

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Significant investments are being made in intelligent roadway infrastructure; manufacturers are deploying increasingly advanced driver assistance systems; and researchers are racing to develop reliable autonomous vehicles that can take over the task of driving entirely. Despite these remarkable advances fundamental research is needed to develop accurate models of overall vehicle dynamics and potential feedback control for future autonomous and smart vehicle systems. To function effectively, autonomous vehicles must accurately sense and respond to changing roadway conditions. By supporting the acquisition of instrumented wheels-- to provide real-time data generated by the tires interacting with the road surface-- this Major Research Instrumentation award will contribute to U.S. competitiveness in the quickly evolving international automotive sector. These data will allow researchers at Bucknell University, Penn State University and other institutions to conduct experiments, share data and collaborate with others to develop algorithms to determine road conditions from sensors. The improvement in fundamental understanding of the interaction of individual tires operating in-situ with the road will enable continued advances in vehicle control, autonomous vehicle operation, and intelligent roadway systems.

The instrumented wheels supported by this award are designed to capture all six forces and moments that are generated by the tire interacting with the road. A custom-manufactured adapter provides physical connection between the wheel rim and load cells, which in turn transfers tire forces and moments to the vehicle chassis. Wheel forces up to 24 kN and torques up to 7.2 kNm, which represent tire behaviors beyond even the most extreme skidding, can be measured with less than 0.1% error. The sensors will be installed on a drive-by-wire research vehicle with computer-controlled independent front steering and independent rear drive. The vehicle is instrumented with a dual-antenna GPS and inertial measurement sensors that provide measurements of the vehicle kinematics. By comparing wheel force and moment data to steering torque inputs, model predictions, vehicle motion measurements, and pavement measurements, the instrumented wheels enable advanced actuation strategies and unique methods of identifying road surface friction conditions. These data will enable designers to develop adaptive control systems that allow autonomous vehicles to better sense road conditions and to optimize the modeling and use of steering and braking inputs to improve vehicle safety, performance, and efficiency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this MRI project, entitled "MRI: Acquisition of Automotive Tire Force and Moment" was to outfit an existing experimental vehicle dynamics platform with six-axis wheel force transducers. These transducers provide the most direct measurement possible of the forces and moments produced by the tires of a vehicle as they interact with the road. In the field of vehicle dynamics and vehicle control systems, these sensors provide valuable data about the performance of the vehicle which cannot be measured reliably in any other way.

The main objective of this project has been successful. The "P1" prototype vehicle dynamics research vehicle, operated by PI Craig Beal at Bucknell University and seen (prior to transducer installation) in Figure 1, has been outfitted with a pair of LW12.8 wheel force transducers. The sensors, seen in Figure 2, were commissioned and validated via experiments performed on a skid-pad operated by Penn State University.

Another of the outcomes of this project with broader impact was to create a publically-available repository of high-fidelity vehicle dynamics data. Data like these exist, but are generally in the possession of racing teams and automotive manufacturers. These organizations, by nature, are disincentivized to share their data. Once validation of the transducers was complete, data sets from P1 were added to the web page at http://www.bucknell.edu/p1garage for public download. The web page also includes parametric data about the research vehicle, a data dictionary to describe the data format, utility scripts to ease the processing of data from the vehicle, and a request form for experimentation using the research vehicle with the NSF-funded transducers.

The addition of the wheel force transducers also enabled investigations into estimating the road surface friction conditions from measurements in the steering system of the vehicle, a key part of the intellectual merit of this project. In particular, the P1 research vehicle has separate left and right steer-by-wire steering systems that are controlled by a central computer.

With the addition of the wheel force transducers, it was possible to identify operating regimes in which it was possible to sense the road surface friction conditions from each of the wheels, with the observation that the inner and outer wheel in a turn has different measurement capabilities, depending on the vehicle speed and steering angle. An algebraic estimation algorithm was implemented and validated, demonstrating the efficacy of the approach. A still image of the validation experimentation is provided in Figure 3. The results were detailed in the following journal article:

Craig E. Beal (2020), Rapid Road Friction Estimation using Independent Left/Right Steering Torque Measurements, Vehicle System Dynamics, 58:3, 377-403, DOI: 10.1080/00423114.2019.1580377

The proposal for this work also hypothesized that additional model fidelity may be needed to describe the mechanics of low speed steering, an area with limited publication history. A significant challenge in this work is separating out effects of steering the tires against a road surface versus those of the vehicle beginning a cornering maneuver. The independence of the left and right steering systems on the P1 vehicle allowed for investigation of the steering dynamics by steering the wheels symmetrically inward or outward, cancelling the cornering forces but generating the slips with the road. A model of the steering and tire dynamics that better described the forces and torques generated in the steering system resulted from this work. Furthermore, this model was also inverted to develop a road surface friction estimator that works at very low speeds, including conditions where the vehicle is stationary but the steering is activated. An image showing stationary testing on an ice patch is provided in Figure 4. This estimator, and the associated model, were detailed in the following journal articles:

Craig E. Beal & Sean Brennan (2020), Friction Detection from Stationary Steering Manoeuvres, Vehicle System Dynamics, 58:11, 1736-1765, DOI: 10.1080/00423114.2019.1645862

Craig E. Beal & Sean Brennan (2020), Modeling and Friction Estimation for Automotive Steering Torque at Very Low Speeds, Vehicle System Dynamics, DOI: 10.1080/00423114.2019.1708416

In addition to the direct developments of products with intellectual merit, this project has also provided the equipment to engage in additional projects. The key follow-on project is the following collaborative NSF Cyber-physical Systems grant:

NSF #1932509: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Automated Discovery of Data Validity for Safety-Critical Feedback Control in a Population of Connected Vehicles, 10/1/19 ? 9/31/21.

Bucknell University is a primarily undergraduate institution that does not grant Ph.D. degrees. This project has had additional broader impact in that it has provided opportunities to PI Beal and several Bucknell undergraduate students. The students have been able to participate in the integration of instrumentation, the development of auxiliary subsystems on the research platform, and have participated in data gathering and processing. PI Beal has been able to expand his research collaborations with colleagues at large research institutions, enabling larger investigations and increased productivity.
